keyTakeAways: Peru’s Interim President Jose Jeri has declared a 30-day state of emergency in the capital, Lima, to manage widespread protests and rising crime.
The emergency allows the government to deploy the army, restrict freedom of assembly, and suspend constitutional rights, raising concerns about civil liberties.
The protests are driven by Gen-Z activists demanding accountability for corruption and organized crime, with recent violence including one death and around 100 injuries.
Extortion cases have surged to 18,000 this year—up 30% from last year—and are linked to a rise in homicides (1,690 from January to September 2025, up from 1,502 in 2024).
The previous state of emergency under Dina Boluarte in March 2025 failed to reduce crime after the murder of singer Paul Flores, indicating a pattern of ineffective emergency responses.
Jose Jeri, who succeeded Dina Boluarte after her impeachment on October 10, 2025, is committed to continuing the emergency and will serve as interim president until July 2026.
Al Jazeera’s Mariana Sanchez reported that the government did not specify how it would gather intelligence to combat extortion, raising transparency concerns.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Peru’s interim president, Jose Jeri, has declared a 30-day state of emergency in the capital, Lima, following weeks of antigovernment protests driven by Gen-Z activists over corruption and rising organized crime. The move allows military deployment and suspension of constitutional rights, including freedom of assembly. The emergency follows the removal of former President Dina Boluarte after impeachment, and comes amid a surge in extortion cases—estimated at 18,000 this year—linked to a 30% increase from the previous year and a rise in homicides. A prior state of emergency under Boluarte in March 2025 failed to curb crime after the murder of singer Paul Flores, highlighting the challenges of addressing crime through emergency measures. The lack of clarity in how intelligence will be gathered to combat extortion raises transparency concerns. Protests turned violent on Thursday, resulting in one death and 100 injuries, including police and journalists, and Jeri has affirmed he will not resign.
title: State of emergency declared in Peru’s capital amid protests
